questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mickey Finn (Alcohol + Chloral hydrate):
This is a knockout mixture/ knockdout drops historically used to stupefy or incapacitate a person. Chloral hydrate, when combined with alcohol, produces a potentiated depressant effect on the CNS, leading to drowsiness or unconsciousness.

Speed Ball (Heroin + Cocaine):
A dangerous combination of a stimulant (cocaine) and a depressant (heroin) injected together. The opposing pharmacologic effects can lead to arrhythmias, respiratory depression, and sudden death.

Crack (Cocaine + Baking soda):
Formed by heating cocaine hydrochloride with sodium bicarbonate (baking soda) and water. The result is cocaine free base, which produces a short, intense euphoric high when smoked.

Hot Shot (Heroin + Strychnine):
A lethal combination where strychnine is mixed with heroin to intensify its euphoric effect. The toxicity results from strychnine-induced convulsions leading to death.

Key Takeaways:

  • Mickey Finn: Sedative mixture (alcohol + chloral hydrate).
  • Speed Ball: Opposing drug mix (heroin + cocaine).
  • Crack: Freebase cocaine prepared with baking soda.
  • Hot Shot: Potentially lethal mix (heroin + strychnine).

questions.text: Perjury is punishable under?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Under the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (2023), perjury (giving or fabricating false evidence in a judicial proceeding) is addressed by Section 229 "Punishment for false evidence". That section prescribes penalties (imprisonment up to 7 years and fine) for those who intentionally give or fabricate false evidence in any judicial proceeding.

While Section 227 BNS defines the offense of "Giving false evidence", it does not prescribe the punishment

Explanation of Other Options:

Section 227 BNS (Option A): Defines giving false evidence (i.e., perjury in the form of false statements under oath), but does not prescribe punishment for it.

Section 228 BNS (Option B): Deals with fabricating false evidence (e.g. creating false documents or entries) rather than directly giving false evidence under oath.

Section 234 BNS (Option D): Concerns issuing or signing a false certificate, which is a related offense but distinct from perjury (false testimony under oath).

Key Takeaways:

  • Giving false evidence is the act/definition of perjury (Section 227).
  • Punishment for perjury is provided under Section 229 BNS.
  • Fabricating evidence and issuing false certificates are related but separate offenses (Sections 228, 234).

References: https://devgan.in/all_sections_bns.php

questions.text: Direction given by a person that, in future if he/she becomes terminally ill and becomes an incompetent patient whether to give medical treatment or not is known as
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An Advance Medical Directive (AMD), also called a Living Will, is a written document in which a competent individual specifies in advance what medical treatment they wish to receive or refuse if they later become incapable of making decisions due to terminal illness or unconsciousness.

In India, the Supreme Court judgment in Common Cause vs Union of India (2018) recognized the legal validity of advance medical directives, allowing terminally ill patients to refuse life-prolonging medical interventions such as mechanical ventilation or artificial nutrition. Also as per mental health act 2017, who is not a minor has a right to make an advance medical directive

The directive becomes operative only when the individual loses decision-making capacity and is confirmed by a medical board as per guidelines.Thus, the description in the question precisely refers to an Advance Medical Directive.

Explanation of Other Options:

Advance directive (Option A): Generic term encompassing any pre-stated wishes about medical or personal decisions when the individual is incapacitated. However, in medical law, the specific term for refusal or acceptance of life-sustaining treatment is Advance Medical Directive.

Testamentary capacity (Option C): Refers to a person's legal competence to make a valid will (testament) about distribution of property after death unrelated to medical treatment decisions.

Palliative care (Option D): Comprehensive care aimed at relieving suffering and improving quality of life for terminally ill patients it is a treatment philosophy, not a directive or legal document.

Key Takeaways:

  • Advance Medical Directive = Living Will.
  • Allows refusal of life-support measures when terminally ill and incompetent.
  • Recognized by Supreme Court of India (2018) under right to die with dignity (Article 21).
  • Must be written, signed before witnesses, and attested as per prescribed format.

References:

  • Common Cause vs Union of India, Supreme Court of India, 2018.

questions.text:
True about keraunographic burns
A. Seen in all cases of lightening
B. It's a class of burn
C. Follows vascular channels
D. Disappears in about 1-2 days
E. Pink to brownish in colour
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Keraunographic (Filigree/Lichtenberg's flower/ Arborescent burns or Feathering) are superficial, irregular, thin, and tortuous markings resembling the branches of a tree and indicate the paths taken by the lightning discharge and fade within 1-2 days if the person survives. They are rare and represent the current's track/electron-shower effects (not true thermal burns). Seen in 20 - 33% of cases. Pink to brownish in colour. Most common site is shoulder and flanks. It is due to staining of tissues with haemoglobin by rupture of RBCs, along the path of current.

Explanation of Other Options:

Seen in all cases of lightning (Statement A): False - these marks are seen rarely, not universally.

It's a class of burn (Statement B): False - Although often called "burns" keraunographic marks are not true burns. They result from electrical and capillary phenomena, not tissue coagulation or heat injury.

Follows vascular channels (Statement C): False - the pattern indicates the discharge path (electron showers/fascial planes); the mechanism is not described as tracking along blood vessels.

Key Takeaways:

  • Keraunographic burns (Lichtenberg figures) are pathognomonic of lightning
  • They are not thermal burns but electrical flow markings.
  • Transient (1-2 days)
  • Often pink to brownish, fern-like, and non-blistering.

choices.text: i, ii, iii, and iv only

questions.text:
Medical negligence by a doctor can be booked under BNS sections:
i. 125
ii. 125a
iii. 125b
iv. 106
v. 304a
questions.solution:
Explanation:

With the implementation of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) 2023, several provisions from the Indian Penal Code (IPC) have been renumbered or reclassified.

  • Section 106 BNS - Causing death by negligence - (1) Whoever causes death of any person by doing any rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, and shall also be liable to fine; and if such act is done by a registered medical practitioner while performing medical procedure, he shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, and shall also be liable to fine.
  • Section 125 BNS - Whoever does any act so rashly or negligently as to endanger human life or the personal safety of others, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months or with fine which may extend to two thousand five hundred rupees, or with both, but-
    • (a) where hurt is caused, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both;
    • (b) where grievous hurt is caused, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees, or with both.

Thus, a doctor's negligent act may fall under:

  • 125 BNS (causing hurt),
  • 125(a) BNS (causing grievous hurt),
  • 125(b) BNS (endangering life/personal safety), and
  • 106 BNS (causing death by negligence).

The former IPC 304-A (v) has been repealed and replaced by Section 106 BNS.

Therefore, the combination of i, ii, iii, and iv correctly covers all applicable BNS provisions for medical negligence.

questions.text: The Following is victim of firearm injury. What is the suspected distance of the shot?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the given image, there is a circular wound with Blackening and tattooing, without singeing and burning suggestive of wound caused by rifled firearm near shot.

  1. Contact shot - here the muzzle end is in contact with body. It may be firm/hard/tight contact or loose contact or angled contact.
  2. Close shot - here the victim is within the distance travelled by flame.
  3. Near shot - here the victim is within the range of soot and smoke but outside the range of flame.
  4. Intermediate shot - here the victim is within the range of powder particles but outside the range of soot and smoke.
  5. Distant shot - here the victim is beyond the range of all the products of firing except the bullet.

Appearance of wounds in various ranges in rifled firearms:

  • Contact shot:
    • Firm contact: Wound of entry + Muzzle impression. (In case of contact shots over bony areas like head and sternum, it appears as cruciate shaped wound)
  • Loose contact: Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar + Blackening (corona) + Burning & singeing (Muzzle impression is unlikely)
  • Angled contact: Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar + Partial muzzle Impression + Burning & Singeing + Blackening + Tattooing.
  • Close shot (Option D): Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar + Burning & Singeing + Blackening + Tattooing.

 

  • Near shot: Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar + Blackening + Tattooing.
  • Intermediate shot (Option B): Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar + Tattooing.
  • Distant shot (Option A); Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar.

Exception: Contact shot on bony areas (head, sternum) > Escape of gas between skin and bone> Formation of temporary bulge > Forcible escape of gas through the wound of entry > Splitting of skin > Cruciate / Stellate shape > Large irregular wound.

questions.text: Match the given diagnostics tests for poisoning
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Marquis test - Opium (Opiates): Marquis reagent (formaldehyde + conc. H₂SO₄) produces a purple red / violet color and finally blue with opiates; it is a presumptive test for opium alkaloids

Kunkel's test (tannic acid test): - Carbon monoxide: In this test, blood containing carboxyhemoglobin retains its bright red color when tannic acid is added to the blood

Cavett's test - Alcohol: A chemical oxidation test used for ethyl alcohol estimation, where dichromate is reduced to chromic sulfate producing a green color in proportion to alcohol content

Lee-Jones test - Cyanide Detects hydrocyanic acid or cyanide salts by forming a greenish-blue complex.

Key Takeaways:

  • Marquis test → Opiates (purple)
  • Kunkel's test → Carbon monoxide (bright red COHb)
  • Cavett's test → Alcohol (green color)
  • Lee-Jones test → Cyanide (greenish-blue complex)

questions.text:
Which of the following are features of female skull?
A. Prominent glabella
B. Prominent frontal eminence
C. Prominent parietal eminence
D. Round orbit
E. Prominent zygoma
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sex differentiation in skulls is based on the degree of robustness, size, and development of bony prominences. Female skulls are generally smaller, lighter, smoother, and more rounded, while male skulls show greater muscular markings and projections due to stronger muscle attachments.

B. Prominent frontal eminence: True - females have more prominent and rounded frontal eminences, giving the forehead a smooth, vertical appearance.

C. Prominent parietal eminence: True - the parietal eminences are well developed in females, contributing to the more rounded contour of the skull vault.

D. Round orbit: True - the orbital margins in females are rounded and smoother, whereas in males they are square or blunt.

Explanation of Other Options:

A. Prominent glabella: False -in females, the glabella is smooth and less projecting, while in males it is prominent and more pronounced.

E. Prominent zygoma: False - females have less prominent zygomatic arches; in males, they are heavier and more pronounced.

Key Takeaways:

  • Female Skull: Smooth surface, rounded vault, frontal and parietal eminences prominent, round orbits, less prominent glabella and zygomatic arches.
  • Male Skull: Heavy, rugged, prominent glabella and superciliary arches, square orbits, well-developed zygoma, and sloping forehead.

questions.text: Any hurt is grievous, provided the victim is unable to follow his ordinary pursuit for a minimum period of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Under Section 116 BNS - Grievous Hurt, clause (8) states that hurt is grievous if it causes the victim to be unable to follow his ordinary pursuits for fifteen days (among other conditions) when not otherwise covered by the specific categories of grievous hurt.

Sec. 116 BNS → The following kinds of hurt only are designated as "grievous" namely:-

(a) Emasculation;

(b) Permanent privation of the sight of either eye;

(c) Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear;

(d) Privation of any member or joint;

(e) Destruction or permanent impairing of the powers of any member or joint;

(f) Permanent disfiguration of the head or face;

(g) Fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth;

(h) Any hurt which endangers life or which causes the sufferer to be during the space of fifteen days in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his ordinary pursuits.

Key Takeaways:

  • BNS defines grievous hurt under Section 116.
  • The clause for incapacity of "ordinary pursuits" changed from 20 to 15 days under BNS.
  • The other clauses include endangerment to life and severe bodily pain.

References:

  • Devgan: Section 116 BNS - BNS Section 116 - Grievous hurt. | Devgan.in

  • BNS English Bare Act, April 2024 release - Section 116 - BNS_English_30-04-2024.pdf

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presented to the emergency with extensive burns. The patient had grade 3 burns on the face, back upper arms and forearms along with singeing of hairs. Which of these is not a proof of inhalation burns?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Inhalation injury is defined as injury to the oropharynx, nasopharynx, trachea, bronchi, or lungs caused by inhalation of smoke, hot gases, or chemical irritants.

  • Soot deposit inside the mouth or posterior pharynx is a direct result of inhaling smoke particles.
  • Oxides of nitrogen and other combustion gases can react with airway secretions to give rise to yellowish sputum.
  • Mucosal injury due to hot gases can lead to hoarseness and stridor because of edema of the laryngeal mucosa.

However, singeing of eyebrows and facial hair results from direct flame exposure, not from inhalation of smoke or heated gases. It indicates external facial burns, not internal airway involvement- hence, it is not a proof of inhalation burns.

Key Takeaways:

  • Inhalation injury = airway injury due to hot gases, smoke, or toxic chemicals.
  • Singeing= external flame effect; not diagnostic of inhalation burns.
  • Always assess airway patency early in burn patients with facial burns or voice changes

questions.text:
Regarding PASV
A. Lower dose in infant as compared to adults
B. Sensitivity test must be done before ASV
C. Useful for venom associated coagulopathy in viper bites
D. Cobra venom acts at presynaptic region
E. Common krait venom causes both internal and external ophthalmoplegia
questions.solution:
Explanation:

ASV (Anti-Snake Venom) is the only specific antidote against snake envenomation. It neutralizes circulating venom components but cannot reverse already fixed neurotoxins.

  • Viper venomis hemotoxic and causes venom-associated coagulopathy due to activation of clotting factors and fibrinogen degradation; hence, ASV is useful in viper bites.
  • Common krait venomis neurotoxic, causing both internal and external ophthalmoplegia, leading to ptosis and paralysis of ocular muscles.
  • Cobra venom, in contrast, acts postsynaptically, blocking acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

Children and pregnant women require the same ASV dose as adults, since the amount of venom injected by the snake is independent of body weight.

Test doses for ASV should not be given, as they do not predict hypersensitivity or anaphylaxis and may, in fact, pre-sensitize the patient to a more severe reaction.

Explanation of Satements:

A. Lower dose in infants- Incorrect. Venom dose injected is similar for all; ASV dosing is not weight-based.

B. Sensitivity test before ASV - Incorrect. Test doses are obsolete as they are unreliable and increase risk of sensitization.

C. Useful for viper bite coagulopathy - Correct. Viper venom is hemotoxic; ASV neutralizes circulating venom.

D. Cobra venom acts at presynaptic region - Incorrect. Cobra venom acts at postsynaptic receptors.

E. Common krait venom causes ophthalmoplegia - Correct. Due to neurotoxin affecting both internal and external ocular muscles.

Key Takeaways:

  • ASV is not species-specific; it neutralizes major Indian snake venoms (cobra, krait, Russell's viper, saw-scaled viper).
  • Dose is same for all ages and pregnancy.
  • Test doses are not recommended.
  • Cobra = postsynaptic block, Krait = presynaptic neurotoxicity, Viper = hemotoxicity.

choices.text: Causing miscarriage with the consent of the mother
Causing miscarriage without the consent of the mother
Causing death of the mother by miscarriage
Causing death of quick unborn child while trying to kill mother

questions.text: Section 90 of BNS deals with
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Under Section 90 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) 2023, the law addresses cases where death is caused by an act done with the intent to cause miscarriage.

The section clearly states that:

"Whoever causes the death of a woman by an act done with intent to cause her miscarriage shall be punished with imprisonment for life or with imprisonment which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine."

This offence recognizes the aggravated form of miscarriage, where the procedure or act intended to terminate pregnancy results in the death of the woman, irrespective of her consent.

Explanation of Other Options:

Causing miscarriage with the consent of the mother (Option A): Dealt with under Section 88 BNS, which corresponds to IPC Section 312 - punishment for miscarriage with consent, except when done in good faith to save her life.

Causing miscarriage without the consent of the mother (Option B): Covered under Section 89 BNS, equivalent to IPC Section 313 - more severe because consent is absent.

Causing death of quick unborn child while trying to kill mother (Option C): Covered under Section 92 BNS, which pertains to acts causing the death of a "quick unborn child" and is analogous to culpable homicide.

Key Takeaways:

  • Section 88 BNS: Miscarriage with woman's consent.
  • Section 89 BNS: Miscarriage without woman's consent.
  • Section 90 BNS: Death caused to woman by act intended to cause miscarriage.
  • Section 91 BNS: Act done with intent to prevent child from being born alive or to cause its death after birth.
  • Section 92 BNS: Death of quick unborn child by act amounting to culpable homicide.

References:

Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), 2023 - Sections 88-92, Chapter on "Offences Affecting the Human Body." - BNS Section 90 - Death caused by act done with intent to cause miscarriage. | Devgan.in

questions.text:
i - Swallow tail may be seen in stab wounds
ii - Stretch lacerations are caused by horizontal force
iii - Fish tailing may be seen in incised wounds
iv - Bleeding is usually more in lacerated wounds than incised wounds
questions.solution:
Explanation:

i - Swallow tail may be seen in stab wounds:

Incorrect. Swallow tail refers to tearing at the ends of a lacerated wound, where angles diverge from the main wound line. This pattern occurs due to overstretching and tearing of the skin by blunt force, not in stab wounds.

ii - Stretch lacerations are caused by horizontal force:

Incorrect. Stretch lacerations are caused by tangential or shearing forces, not purely horizontal forces. They occur when skin is overstretched and splits, commonly seen when blunt force acts tangentially across a surface.

iii - Fish tailing may be seen in incised wounds:

Incorrect. Normally single edged knife causes a wedge-shaped wound; but sometimes the blunt end of the blade may tear the skin in the form of the shape of a tail of a fish, known as fish tailing

iv - Bleeding is usually more in lacerated wounds than incised wounds:

Bleeding is usually less in lacerated wounds than incised wounds due to crushing of the vessels.

Key Takeaways:

  • Swallow-tail wound: Seen in lacerations, not stabs.
  • Stretch laceration: Caused by tangential force.
  • Fish-tailing: Seen in stab wounds by single-edged knives.
  • Bleeding: More in incised wounds than lacerations.

All statements are incorrect

questions.text:
In case of head injury
1. Lucid interval is seen most commonly in subdural haemorrhage
2. Most common source of bleeding is rupture of posterior branch of middle meningeal artery
3. Extradural haemorrhage is always associated with skull fracture
4. The minimum amount of blood required to manifest symptoms in case of extradural haemorrhage is 35 ml.
5. Kernohan's notch is seen on the contralateral side of extradural haemorrhage
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  1. Lucid interval is seen most commonly in subdural haemorrhage - Incorrect.
    • Lucid interval is most commonly seen in extradural haemorrhage (EDH), not subdural. It occurs due to an initial loss of consciousness after trauma, followed by a temporary recovery period (lucid phase) before neurological deterioration as blood accumulates.
  2. Most common source of bleeding is rupture of posterior branch of middle meningeal artery - Correct.
    • In EDH, the posterior branch of the middle meningeal artery is the most frequent source of bleeding as it courses diagonally backwards across the squamous temporal bone on the lateral wall of the cranium. The anterior (frontal) branch is rarely the source of bleeding.
  3. Extradural haemorrhage is always associated with skull fracture -Incorrect.
    • Though 85% of EDH cases are associated with a skull fracture, 15% can occur without it. Therefore, it is not always associated with a fracture.
  4. Minimum amount of blood required to manifest symptoms is 35 ml - Correct.
    • Clinical features of EDH typically appear once about 35 ml of blood accumulates in the extradural space, leading to increased intracranial pressure and brain compression.
  5. Kernohan's notch is seen on the contralateral side of extradural haemorrhage - Correct.
    • Kernohan's notch is a compression of the contralateral cerebral peduncle against the tentorial edge due to brain herniation.
    • This produces false localizing signs, where the paralysis appears on the same side as the lesion, though the notch is contralateral.

Key Takeaways:

  • Lucid interval → Extradural haemorrhage, not subdural.
  • Posterior branch of middle meningeal artery→ Commonest source of bleeding.
  • Skull fracture present in ~85%, but not all EDH.
  • Symptomatic volume:~35 ml of blood.
  • Kernohan's notch: Seen contralateral to the lesion anatomically, but motor deficit appears ipsilateral (false localizing sign).

questions.text:
Regarding semen,
1.Yellow needle shaped crystals of Spermine picrate is seen in Florence test
2.Dark brown rhombic crystals of Choline iodide are seen in Barberio's test
3.Both Choline and Spermine can be detected by Thin Layer Chromatography
4.Old seminal stains up to 6 months can be detected by the presence of CPK
5.Detection of sperm specific LDH isoenzyme can confirm seminal stain
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  1. Yellow needle-shaped crystals of spermine picrate are seen in Florence test- Incorrect.
    In Barberio's test, spermine present in semen reacts with picric acid to form yellowish needle-shaped crystals of spermine picrate.
  2. Dark brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide are seen in Barberio' test - Incorrect.
    In Florence's test, choline from semen reacts with Florence reagent (potassium iodide + iodine + distilled water) to form brownish rhomboid-shaped crystals of choline iodide.
  3. Both choline and spermine can be detected by Thin Layer Chromatography - Correct.
    Thin Layer Chromatography (TLC) is the only chemical test that can detect both choline and spermine simultaneously in seminal stains.
  4. Old seminal stains up to 6 months can be detected by the presence of CPK - Correct.
    Creatine phosphokinase (CPK) is a stable enzyme found in high concentrations in semen (385-1400 U/mL).
    Even after drying, it can be detected up to 6 months after soiling, confirming seminal origin.
  5. Detection of sperm-specific LDH isoenzyme can confirm seminal stain - Correct.
    Detection of sperm-specific LDH (LDH-X) isoenzyme by electrophoresis or immunological methods confirms the presence of semen - this serves as an absolute proof, along with microscopic identification of spermatozoa.

Key Takeaways:

  • Barberio's test → Spermine + Picric acid → Yellowish needle-shaped crystals (spermine picrate)
  • Florence test → Choline + Florence reagent → Brown rhombic crystals (choline iodide)
  • TLC → Detects both choline and spermine
  • CPK enzyme → Detectable for up to 6 months in old seminal stains
  • LDH isoenzyme (LDH-X) → Confirmatory test for semen detection

questions.text:
In case of cyanide poisoning
i - Smell of bitter almonds is a consistent finding
ii - Patients with achlorhydria have the poor prognosis than others
iii - Hydroxocobalamin is the drug of choice
iv - Cyanosis is a late feature
questions.solution:
Explanation:

i. Smell of bitter almonds is a consistent finding - Incorrect.

The smell of bitter almonds is not a consistent finding. Only about 60-80% of the population can perceive this odor; the ability is determined by a sex-linked recessive trait. Hence, the absence of odor does not rule out cyanide poisoning.

ii. Patients with achlorhydria have poorer prognosis - Incorrect.

This is false. Achlorhydric patients (those with reduced or absent gastric HCl) are actually less susceptible to cyanide toxicity.

The conversion of cyanide salts (like KCN, NaCN, AgCN) to hydrocyanic acid, the toxic form, occurs in the presence of hydrochloric acid in the stomach. Thus, in achlorhydria, cyanide absorption and toxicity are reduced.

iii. Hydroxocobalamin is the drug of choice -Correct.

Hydroxocobalamin binds with cyanide to form cyanocobalamin (vitamin B12), which is nontoxic and excreted in urine. is considered the antidote of choice in modern toxicology for cyanide poisoning, as it is safer than older treatments like amyl nitrite or sodium thiosulfate.

iv. Cyanosis is a late feature - Correct.

Cyanide inhibits cytochrome oxidase, leading to histotoxic anoxia - oxygen cannot be utilized by tissues even though blood oxygen levels are normal.

Hence, the skin often appears pink or cherry red initially, and cyanosis develops late as tissue hypoxia progresses.

Key Takeaways:

  • Smell of bitter almonds → Not consistent; genetic variability affects perception.
  • Achlorhydria → Decreases risk of cyanide poisoning (not increases).
  • Hydroxocobalamin → Preferred antidote; forms cyanocobalamin.
  • Cyanosis → Late finding due to histotoxic hypoxia.

choices.text: Working in government hospitals, where patients are not charged at all
Working in private hospitals where services are rendered free of charge to everybody
Working in hospitals where only a nominal registration fee is collected, and all other services are free of cost
Working in hospitals where some patients are charged, and some are not charged

questions.text: The doctors NOT exempted from Consumer Protection Act (CPA) are
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Doctors Exempted from CPA:
The Consumer Protection Act (CPA) applies only when there is a payment or consideration for services. Medical practitioners or institutions providing services entirely free of charge are exempted.

  1. Government hospitals where patients are not charged at all -Exempted, as treatment is fully free.
  2. Private hospitals providing services free of charge to all - Exempted, as no commercial transaction occurs.
  3. Hospitals collecting only nominal registration fees but offering all other services free - Exempted, as such minor fees are not considered professional charges under CPA.

Doctors NOT Exempted from CPA:

  1. Private hospitals where all patients are charged - These are clearly covered under CPA, as service is rendered for payment.
  2. Hospitals where some patients are charged and others are not - Also covered under CPA, as the institution cannot claim full exemption when any part of its services involves payment. The paying patients qualify as consumers under the Act.

Thus, option (d) - doctors working in hospitals where some patients are charged, and some are not - are not exempted under the CPA.

Key Takeaways:

  • CPA applies when services are rendered for a fee.
  • Free government or charitable hospitals are exempted.
  • Mixed model hospitals (some free, some paid) fall within CPA jurisdiction.
  • Nominal registration fees do not qualify as a paid service under CPA.

questions.text: Pink teeth in decomposed bodies is seen in case of death due to
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pink Teeth Phenomenon:

The pink coloration of teeth seen in decomposed bodies is not related to any particular cause of death.

It occurs due to the seepage of hemoglobin (Hb) and its derivatives such as protoporphyrin into the dentinal tubules of the tooth.

This infiltration gives a distinct pink or reddish hue, especially in the neck and root regions of the teeth.

Time of Occurrence:

The change is typically observed 1-2 weeks after death, when decomposition progresses enough for hemoglobin breakdown and diffusion.

Associated Conditions:

Pink teeth are commonly seen in bodies recovered from water, but this is an association, not a causative factor.

It can also occur in other conditions of prolonged putrefaction or humid environments, irrespective of how the person died.

Key Distinction:

Unlike CO poisoning (which produces cherry-red skin and blood) or cyanide poisoning (which may cause pinkish skin), pink teeth do not indicate poisoning or asphyxia - it is purely a postmortem phenomenon related to decomposition.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cause: Seepage of Hb and porphyrin derivatives into dentin.
  • Timing: Appears 1-2 weeks postmortem.
  • Association: Often seen in water immersion or advanced decomposition.
  • Diagnostic value: None - not indicative of cause of death.

questions.text: Which among the following is the 'En bloc' method used in autopsy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Letulle's Technique (En Masse / En Bloc Method):

  • Described by: Letulle
  • Meaning of En Masse / En Bloc: "All together" or "as one large block."
  • In this technique, the cervical, thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed together as a single large block.
  • Key Feature:
    • All organs remain connected with their natural attachments.
    • Allows examination of interrelationships between organ systems.
    • Commonly demonstrated in medical colleges for teaching due to its clarity of anatomical relationships.

Other Evisceration Methods (for Comparison):

  1. Virchow's Technique:
    • Organ-by-organ removal method.
    • Each organ is removed individually and dissected separately.
    • Useful when studying specific organ pathology.
    • Most commonly used method in India due to simplicity.
  2. Ghon's Technique:
    • Block-by-block dissection method.
    • Cervical, thoracic, abdominal, and urogenital organs are removed as separate organ blocks.
    • Balances speed and detailed examination.
  3. Rokitansky's Technique:
    • In-situ dissection of organs.
    • Organs are examined within the body cavity with minimal evisceration.
    • Used in infected or suspected infectious cases to reduce contamination risk.

Key Takeaways:

  • Letulle's (En Bloc) → All organs removed together.
  • Virchow's → Organ by organ.
  • Ghon's → Block by block.
  • Rokitansky's → In situ (no removal).
